 There are estimated to be 86,500 people with HIV in Britain, with a quarter unaware that they have an infection. About 42% of people infected with HIV in 2009 were homosexual men, according to the Terrence Higgins Trust, the HIV charity. 
 
 Homosexual men are also at risk of passing on other sexually transmitted diseases such as syphilis. 
 
 Gay rights campaigners have pushed for the ban to be lifted, saying many homosexual men are in long-term monogamous relationships, practise safe sex or have been celibate for years. 
 
 A Government source said: "A complete ban is unfair and discriminatory but we need to protect public health, so the 10-year rule is what is being considered
 
 Gay rights leaders would rather peoples health be at risk than to act responsibly and recognise they are at a higher risk of HIV than heterosexuals.

 Homosexual men are also at risk of passing on other sexually transmitted diseases such as syphilis.

 Public health decisions should be made on dispassionate balancing of risk and benefit. We infringe on personal rights all the time with these decision because, by definition, the decisions are about populations, not individuals. 
 
 If the the risk of allowing this (letting some HIV+ blood that was missed in the screening process into the blood banking system) outweighs the benefit (having all the needed blood products available to save lives), then it does not makes sense. There are mathematical models that one can used to actual make this decision. 
 
 If this decision was based on sound science. I would agree with it. If made purely for political reasons that would harm public health, bad move I say. 
 
 It comes down to risk and benefit. If I was bleeding to death, and my only option was some HIV+ blood, I'd take it. I'd risk AIDS over immediate death. That is an absurd example perhaps, but I say it to point out the risks are relative to the underlying issue. I don't know what the risk is of obtaining blood from men who say (always tricky to trust) they have not had sex with men for a decade and slip through the screening test could be. Maybe someone thinks it is so low as to be acceptable. 
 
 It would be OK if after a dispassionate, objective and scientific evaluation it was determined to be an acceptable risk. That's what you do in public health decisions. On the other hand if this is too risky, this might be perfectly appropriate "discrimination". 
 
 My point is (really, I do have one) that I don't know the numbers upon which this decision was made. If they are similar to other blood bank policies, sounds cool to me.

 No. I said I neither agree nor disagree without knowing the numbers. Perhaps doing it this way (allowing those who say they have been celibate for 10 years to donate) reduces the risk to an acceptably low degree. I don't know. You can't make these decisions by simply looking at that one percentage. You have to take into account lots of other things - what is the percentage of seropositivity in the the subset in question, the inherent accuracies of the test, the number of units of blood that would be generated or lost, and oodles of other stuff I know nothing about. 
 
 I am saying we should not base these decisions on idealogies either way. 
 
 I have seen overly restrictive public health policies that were wildly expensive and didn't help anything. Most of the errors are in this direction. 
 
 I did disagree that this is illlegal discrimination (though I really don't know that for sure as I do not know UK law). I feel that public health population-based decisions often, and rightly, trumps individual rights occasionally.
 
 I am not calling them maroons as I can't be sure if they are acting wisely or not. I reserve that term for those whom I am sure are stupid.
